text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Finnish Foreign Minister Tarja Halonen said that visa-free travel may be introduced from this summer during her meeting with Estonian Foreign Minister Toomas Ilves.
- A students' and secondary school pupils' rally in Tartu against reduced travel subsidies by the government turned violent and needed police action.
- President Lennart Meri has convened the national defence council today to discuss recent developments with the border agreement with Russia.
- The TSM company hopes to begin building the Tallinn port area this year.
- The ruling coalition has initiated a draft law on customs tariffs, which enables the government to introduce protective tariffs.
- The draft law on energy production has reached the parliament.

- The State Court allowed the appeal of three politicians on the president's oath of conscience to proceed. The oath is taken by all elected officials and states that they have not cooperated with foreign intelligence or repressive agencies. The three MPs alleged that Meri collobrated with the KGB.
- Interviews with MPs of different parties on the rejection of a draft law, which proposed to ban electoral unions and blocs from parliamentary elections.
- A wooden board factory was opened at Iisaku in Eastern Estonia.
- A bank dealer claims that transactions with share purchase options have created a dozen millionaires in Estonia in the last couple of months.
